title: 103_hr107
content:
The Act titled "Congressional Accountability Act of 1993" is cited as the short title. It applies to various sections outlined in the legislation. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies laws related to employment terms, health and safety, and employer-employee rights to Congress, including the Social Security Act, National Labor Relations Act, Fair Labor Standards Act, Civil Rights Act of 1964, Age Discrimination in Employment Act, and Occupational Safety and Health Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends various laws to Congress, including the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967, Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, Rehabilitation Act of 1973, Privacy Act of 1974, Age Discrimination Act of 1975, Ethics in Government Act of 1978, Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, and other provisions related to the Freedom of Information Act and Independent Counsel Provisions. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends various laws to Congress, including provisions for individuals covered by the Act such as Senators, Representatives, employees of Congress, elected officers, Capitol Police members, and employees of Congressional instrumentalities. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends laws to Congress, covering Senators, Representatives, and employees of Congress, including various offices and agencies. It allows Members to consider political affiliation and residence when hiring staff. A conforming amendment repeals a section of the Americans with Disabilities Act. The Disabilities Act of 1990 is repealed, and a small business exemption applies to Members based on the number of employees. SEC. 3. PROMULGATION OF IMPLEMENTING REGULATIONS.

Within 180 days of the Act's enactment, the House of Representatives and the Senate must create rules to implement the Act, in line with Federal law. Failure to do so will result in being subject to Executive agency regulations.

SEC. 4. RIGHT OF APPEAL.

Individuals affected by the Act can appeal actions in Federal court, with rights and remedies similar to private individuals under relevant laws.
